metadata.firstNLines:
This is a [Next.js](https://nextjs.org) project bootstrapped with [`create-next-app`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/api-reference/cli/create-next-app).

## Getting Started

First, run the development server:

```bash
npm run dev
# or
yarn dev
# or
pnpm dev
# or
bun dev
```

Open [http://localhost:3000](http://localhost:3000) with your browser to see the result.

You can start editing the page by modifying `app/page.tsx`. The page auto-updates as you edit the file.

This project uses [`next/font`](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/fonts) to automatically optimize and load [Geist](https://vercel.com/font), a new font family for Vercel.

## Learn More

To learn more about Next.js, take a look at the following resources:

- [Next.js Documentation](https://nextjs.org/docs) - learn about Next.js features and API.
- [Learn Next.js](https://nextjs.org/learn) - an interactive Next.js tutorial.

You can check out [the Next.js GitHub repository](https://github.com/vercel/next.js) - your feedback and contributions are welcome!

app/layout.tsx.name: layout.tsx
app/layout.tsx.upperLevelSummary: Defines the root layout and global metadata while configuring the application's primary fonts. Integrates global CSS styles to provide a consistent visual foundation for all pages.
app/layout.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the root layout for a Next.js application, specifically a calculator project. It performs essential setup tasks including font optimization by configuring the Geist and Geist Mono fonts from Google Fonts as CSS variables. It defines global SEO metadata such as the application title and description. Finally, it exports the 'RootLayout' component, which defines the fundamental HTML structure (html and body tags) and applies typography classes to ensure consistent styling and font availability across all pages in the application.

structure.name: geistSans
structure.summary: Initializes the Geist Sans variable font with a CSS variable name '--font-geist-sans' and specifies the 'latin' subset for optimization.

structure.name: geistMono
structure.summary: Initializes the Geist Mono monospace font with a CSS variable name '--font-geist-mono' and specifies the 'latin' subset.

structure.name: metadata
structure.summary: Defines and exports the SEO metadata object, setting the page title to 'Calculator | Nexhacks Sample' and providing a descriptive summary of the application.

structure.name: RootLayout
structure.summary: The main layout component that wraps the entire application. It accepts 'children' as a prop, renders the base HTML structure with the 'en' language attribute, and applies the font CSS variables to the body element using template literals.

app/page.tsx.name: page.tsx
app/page.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This file defines the Home page component to render a titled calculator within a centered main layout. It serves as the application's root entry point and depends on the Calculator and Visualizer components.
app/page.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the main entry point for a Next.js application's home route. Originally designed to host a Calculator component (now commented out), the current implementation acts as a wrapper for a client-side visualization component. It uses the 'use client' directive to facilitate React's client-side features and defines a full-screen layout using inline CSS to ensure the Visualizer occupies the entire viewport area.

structure.name: Legacy Home Page Block (Commented)
structure.summary: Contains a commented-out version of the Home component which previously imported a Calculator and CSS modules to render a titled calculator interface.

structure.name: Home
structure.summary: The active React functional component that renders the application's main page. It encapsulates the Visualizer component within a main container styled with 100vw and 100vh to ensure it fills the user's screen.

components/Button.tsx.name: Button.tsx
components/Button.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This component renders a customizable calculator button supporting various visual variants and click interactions. It utilizes local CSS module styling and is implemented within the ButtonGrid component to build the user interface.
components/Button.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This file defines a React functional component named Button, designed for a calculator interface. It utilizes TypeScript for type safety, defining a ButtonProps interface to manage button labels, click events, visual variants (number, operator, special, equals), and layout options (wide). The component dynamically generates CSS class names using CSS Modules and a filtering logic to apply styles based on the provided props. Its primary role is to serve as a reusable, stylized input element that returns its value to a parent component upon interaction.

structure.name: ButtonProps
structure.summary: A TypeScript interface defining the expected properties for the Button component, including value (string), onClick (callback function), variant (styling category), and wide (boolean for layout control).

structure.name: Button
structure.summary: The default export functional component that renders a HTML button. It destructures props with default values, manages click events, and computes dynamic CSS classes.

structure.name: handleClick
structure.summary: An internal closure that executes the onClick callback provided in the props, passing the component's current value back to the parent component.

structure.name: classNames logic
structure.summary: A logical block that constructs a dynamic string of CSS classes by accessing the imported styles module. It uses an array with a filter(Boolean) pattern to conditionally apply the 'wide' class and the specific 'variant' class.

components/ButtonGrid.tsx.name: ButtonGrid.tsx

metadata.firstNLines:
import Button from "./Button";
import styles from "./ButtonGrid.module.css";

interface ButtonGridProps {
    onButtonClick: (value: string) => void;
}

/**
 * Calculator button grid component
 * Arranges buttons in a 4x5 grid layout
 */
export default function ButtonGrid({ onButtonClick }: ButtonGridProps) {
    const buttons = [
        { value: "C", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "±", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "%", variant: "special" as const },
        { value: "÷", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "7", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "8", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "9", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "×", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "4", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "5", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "6", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "-", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "1", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "2", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "3", variant: "number" as const },
        { value: "+", variant: "operator" as const },
        { value: "0", variant: "number" as const, wide: true },

components/ButtonGrid.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This component renders a 4x5 grid of interactive calculator buttons to handle user input and operations. It integrates the Button component and local styles for use within the main Calculator interface.
components/ButtonGrid.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The ButtonGrid component serves as the structural layout for a calculator's keypad, organizing individual Button components into a functional grid. It defines a static array of button configurations, specifying labels, visual variants (special, operator, number, equals), and layout properties such as the wide span for the '0' key. By mapping over this configuration, it ensures consistent event handling through a shared callback and maintains separation between data definition and visual presentation.

structure.name: ButtonGridProps
structure.summary: TypeScript interface defining the required props for the component, specifically the onButtonClick callback function.

structure.name: ButtonGrid
structure.summary: The main functional component that initializes the keypad layout and handles the rendering of the calculator's interactive buttons.

structure.name: buttons
structure.summary: A configuration array that stores the data for 19 calculator buttons, defining their display value, semantic variant for styling, and layout behavior (e.g., the 'wide' property for the zero key).

structure.name: return block
structure.summary: The JSX rendering logic that iterates through the buttons array to generate a collection of Button components wrapped in a CSS grid container.

components/Calculator.tsx.name: Calculator.tsx
components/Calculator.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This component manages the calculator's internal state and coordinates the processing of mathematical operations. It integrates core calculation utilities with modular subcomponents for the display and button layout.
components/Calculator.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: This component serves as the central state manager and orchestrator for a React-based calculator application. It manages five distinct state variables—display, previousValue, operation, waitingForOperand, and history—to facilitate complex arithmetic workflows including chained operations, floating-point math, and history tracking. The component utilizes several memoized callback functions (useCallback) to handle specific input types like digits, operators, and clear/delete functions, delegating actual mathematical logic to external utility functions. It acts as a bridge between the user interface elements, specifically the Display and ButtonGrid components, ensuring a cohesive flow of data from button clicks to the visual output.

structure.name: Calculator
structure.summary: The main functional component that initializes calculator state and defines the event handlers for all calculator operations.

structure.name: handleNumber
structure.summary: Updates the display state when a numeric button is clicked, handling the transition from '0' and managing the input of multi-digit numbers.

structure.name: handleDecimal
structure.summary: Appends a decimal point to the current display string, ensuring that only one decimal point can exist in the current operand.

structure.name: handleOperator
structure.summary: Processes mathematical operators; if a calculation is already pending, it performs the previous operation before setting the new operator and updating the calculation history.

structure.name: handleEquals
structure.summary: Executes the pending calculation using the stored previous value, the current operator, and the current display value, then updates the display and history.

structure.name: handleClear
structure.summary: Resets all component state variables to their initial default values, effectively clearing the calculator's memory and display.

structure.name: handleBackspace
structure.summary: Removes the last character from the display string, resetting it to '0' if the length reaches zero or if only a negative sign remains.

structure.name: handleToggleSign
structure.summary: Multiplies the current display value by -1 to toggle between positive and negative values.

structure.name: handlePercent
structure.summary: Converts the current display value into a percentage by dividing it by 100.

structure.name: handleButtonClick
structure.summary: A dispatcher function that receives a button value from the ButtonGrid and executes the corresponding handler (clear, backspace, operator, equals, etc.).

structure.name: return
structure.summary: Renders the UI layout, passing display and history state to the Display component and the click dispatcher to the ButtonGrid component.

components/Display.tsx.name: Display.tsx
components/Display.tsx.upperLevelSummary: This component renders a calculator display that shows the current input value and the history of previous calculations. It is utilized by the Calculator component and depends on a dedicated CSS module for its visual layout.
components/Display.tsx.lowerLevelSummary: The Display.tsx file defines a React functional component designed to serve as the visual interface for a calculator's output screen. It utilizes TypeScript for prop validation via the DisplayProps interface, ensuring that both the current numerical value and the calculation history are passed as strings. The component follows a presentational pattern, focusing on rendering the received data within a styled container using CSS modules. It acts as a stateless leaf component in the UI hierarchy, responsible for the clear separation and display of the calculator's current state and historical context.

structure.name: DisplayProps
structure.summary: An interface that defines the contract for the component's properties, requiring a 'value' string for the main result and a 'history' string for previous operations.

structure.name: Display
structure.summary: The default exported functional component that returns the JSX structure for the calculator display. It renders a parent container containing two distinct divs: one for displaying the calculation history and another for the current input or result, mapping them to specific CSS classes from a module.

eslint.config.mjs.name: eslint.config.mjs
eslint.config.mjs.upperLevelSummary: This file establishes the project's ESLint rules by merging Next.js core web vitals and TypeScript configurations. It exports the final settings and defines global ignore patterns for build artifacts without relying on other local files.
eslint.config.mjs.lowerLevelSummary: This file, `eslint.config.mjs`, serves as the centralized ESLint configuration for a Next.js project, utilizing the modern Flat Config system. It imports predefined rule sets for Next.js Core Web Vitals and TypeScript support to maintain high code quality and performance standards. The configuration aggregates these rules and explicitly defines global ignore patterns using the `globalIgnores` utility. This ensures that build artifacts, output directories, and auto-generated type definitions—specifically `.next/`, `out/`, `build/`, and `next-env.d.ts`—are excluded from the linting process, optimizing execution time and preventing noise from non-source files.

structure.name: eslintConfig
structure.summary: The primary configuration constant initialized via the `defineConfig` utility. It spreads the imported Next.js configurations into a flat array and incorporates a global ignore block to manage which files the linter should process.

structure.name: globalIgnores
structure.summary: A specific configuration entry that defines a list of file and directory patterns to be ignored globally. This block targets standard Next.js build and distribution folders to ensure the linter only evaluates source code.

lib/calculator.ts.name: calculator.ts

metadata.fileDocstring:
*
 * Calculator logic module
 * Contains pure mathematical functions for calculator operations

functionSignatures.name: add
functionSignatures.signature: export function add(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: subtract
functionSignatures.signature: export function subtract(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: multiply
functionSignatures.signature: export function multiply(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: divide
functionSignatures.signature: export function divide(a: number, b: number): number

functionSignatures.name: calculate
functionSignatures.signature: export function calculate(a: number, operation: Operation, b: number): number

lib/calculator.ts.upperLevelSummary: This module provides pure mathematical functions and utilities for core calculator operations, including arithmetic, input parsing, and display formatting. It functions as a dependency-free logic layer utilized by the Calculator component to handle computational tasks.
lib/calculator.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the core logic module for a calculator application, providing a suite of pure mathematical functions and utility methods. It defines the basic arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), including safety checks for division by zero. It utilizes a TypeScript union type 'Operation' to define valid mathematical symbols and a centralized 'calculate' function to dispatch these operations based on the operator provided. Additionally, it includes utility functions for sanitizing string inputs into numbers and sophisticated logic for formatting numerical results for display, handling edge cases such as very large or small numbers through scientific notation and precision constraints.

structure.name: add
structure.summary: Performs addition of two numerical operands and returns the sum.

structure.name: subtract
structure.summary: Performs subtraction by calculating the difference between the first and second numerical operands.

structure.name: multiply
structure.summary: Performs multiplication of two numerical operands and returns the product.

structure.name: divide
structure.summary: Performs division of the dividend by the divisor. It includes a guard clause that throws an Error if the divisor is zero to prevent invalid mathematical operations.

structure.name: Operation
structure.summary: Defines a TypeScript union type representing the valid string literals allowed for mathematical operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division.

structure.name: calculate
structure.summary: A dispatcher function that accepts two operands and an operation symbol. It uses a switch statement to route the inputs to the specific arithmetic function corresponding to the operation.

structure.name: parseInput
structure.summary: Converts string inputs into numbers using parseFloat. It includes a safety check that returns 0 if the input cannot be successfully parsed into a valid number.

structure.name: formatDisplay
structure.summary: Prepares a number for UI display by converting it to a string. It applies scientific notation for extreme magnitudes (very large or very small numbers) and uses precision limiting for long decimal strings to ensure the output fits within typical UI constraints.

next-env.d.ts.name: next-env.d.ts
next-env.d.ts.upperLevelSummary: Provides TypeScript type definitions for Next.js features, global image types, and framework-specific environment configurations. It integrates internal build-generated route types into the project to ensure consistent type safety across the codebase.
next-env.d.ts.lowerLevelSummary: The next-env.d.ts file is a crucial, auto-generated TypeScript declaration file used in Next.js projects to provide type safety and IntelliSense for the framework's internal features. It serves as a bridge between the TypeScript compiler and Next.js, referencing essential type definitions for the core framework and global image types. Additionally, it imports generated route types to enable features like statically typed links. Because Next.js manages this file automatically during development and build cycles, manual modifications are discouraged to prevent them from being overwritten or causing compilation errors.

structure.name: Reference Directives
structure.summary: These triple-slash directives instruct the TypeScript compiler to include global type definitions for Next.js ('next') and image asset imports ('next/image-types/global'), ensuring types for various file formats and Next.js components are recognized globally.

structure.name: Typed Routes Import
structure.summary: Imports the dynamically generated route types from the internal build directory (./.next), which facilitates the 'Typed Routes' feature in Next.js, allowing for type-safe navigation.

structure.name: Maintenance Notice
structure.summary: A comment block providing a warning that the file should not be manually edited and a reference link to the official Next.js documentation regarding TypeScript configuration.

next.config.ts.name: next.config.ts
next.config.ts.upperLevelSummary: Defines configuration settings to customize the Next.js application's build and runtime behavior. Exports a typed configuration object used by the framework and maintains no local dependencies.
next.config.ts.lowerLevelSummary: This file serves as the configuration entry point for a Next.js application using TypeScript. It imports the 'NextConfig' type to ensure type safety and provide developers with auto-completion for available framework options. The file defines a 'nextConfig' constant, currently empty, which acts as a central repository for adjusting core framework behaviors such as build optimization, environment variables, headers, and rewrites. By exporting this object as the default, the Next.js runtime can ingest these settings to customize the application's build and server-side behavior.

structure.name: Import Statement
structure.summary: Imports the NextConfig type from the 'next' package to enable TypeScript type-checking and IDE support for configuration properties.

structure.name: nextConfig
structure.summary: Defines the primary configuration object for the Next.js application. While currently empty, this block is where settings like output modes, experimental features, and plugin configurations are specified.

structure.name: Export Statement
structure.summary: Exports the nextConfig object as the default export, making it accessible to the Next.js build system and dev server.
